content.text: The student places the metre ruler on the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark with the scale of the ruler facing upwards
He places an object Q with its centre on the metre ruler at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Calculate the distance \(y\) from the centre of Q to the \(100.0 \text{cm}\) end of the ruler
The student places a load P of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre ruler
He adjusts the position of the load so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. He measures the distance \(x\) from the centre of P to the zero end of the ruler
He repeats the procedure using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\), \(5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). The values of \(P\) and \(x\) are shown in Table 1.1
Describe the main difficulty that a student has when doing this experiment as accurately as possible
Plot a graph of \(P / \mathsf{N}\) (y-axis) against x/cm (x-axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Use the graph to find the value of \(x\) required to balance the ruler when \(P = 3.5 \text{N}\). Show clearly on the graph how you determined the value of \(x\)
Using apparatus from Fig. 1.1, explain briefly how you would determine the position of the centre of mass of the ruler
A student investigates the balancing of a metre ruler
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Complete the first column of Table 2.1
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). She immediately starts a stop-watch
She continues recording the temperature at 30s intervals. The temperature readings are shown in Table 2.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta =\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water using the equation \(R = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}\), where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
Suggest one change to the experiment that you could make to test the statement
Suggest how to display the results to make it easier to see the trend in the rate of cooling
A student states that the average rate of cooling of the water decreases as the temperature comes nearer to room temperature
Explain briefly why it is good practice to read the thermometer scale at right angles
The student uses a measuring cylinder to measure \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water. She reads the scale at right angles
Suggest another precaution to obtain an accurate reading of the volume of the water
A student investigates the cooling of water under different conditions
Fig. 2.1 shows the set-up
• On Fig. 3.1, draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block
• Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{DC}\), below line \(\mathbf{PC}\), at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal
• Mark with neat crosses (X) the positions for two pins on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment
• Label the positions \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CE}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
The student looks from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block
He adjusts his line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown on Fig. 3.1
State one precaution that you would take in order to produce an accurate ray trace
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between the line \(\mathbf{AB}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CF}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
Calculate the angle \(\theta\) between line CF and the normal to line AB. Show your working
The student moves the transparent block to a new position on the ray-trace sheet, as shown in Fig. 3.2
He places pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) in the same positions used in \(\mathbf{(b)(ii)}\)
He observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the curved side of the block

He places pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_5\), \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
He draws a line \(\mathbf{CF}\) through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\)
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\theta\). State whether your results support the suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
A student investigates the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block
Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 show his ray-trace sheet
Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the change in resistance of a lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased
The following apparatus is available:
· a power supply
· a low-voltage filament lamp
· an ammeter
· a voltmeter
· connecting wires
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in resistance of the lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp and \(I\) is the current in the lamp
You should:
· draw a diagram of the circuit used
· explain briefly how to do the investigation, including how to change the current
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion
